Dear Parents/Guardians,

I hope that this email finds you and your family safe and healthy. As you may or may not be aware of, Governor Cuomo provided guidance on the starting of interscholastic sports earlier this week. In the guidance, certain sports were allowed to begin on September 21.

Since then, concerns have been expressed to the New York State Public High School Athletic Association (NYSPHSAA) about starting on that date, due to the varying teaching models (hybrid or remote).

Throughout next week, meetings will be occurring with the NYSPHSAA. It is my hope that concrete plans will be provided to districts after these meetings. Until the plan is provided to districts, we cannot move forward with sports in the district.

I will continue to provide information as I receive it, and it will be posted on the district website.

Thank you, and have a nice weekend.

Go Sailors
Tom Baker
Athletic Director

At this time, the New York State Public High School Athletic Association (NYSPHSAA), the governing body of New York's interscholastic sports, has recommended that districts begin fall sports on Monday, September 21. However, as of today, state officials have not provided authorization on interscholastic athletics resuming.

With the approval still not in place, the Section One Athletic Council has recommended delaying the process to sign up for fall sports, which the District had hoped could begin this Monday, August 24. Thus, the Family ID portal, on the District website, will not be open on that day to start. We will await further guidance from the state.

Dear Hendrick Hudson Families,

Last week, we communicated that we would adopt a phased-in model for the reopening of our schools. Since then, other districts in our region have decided to take the same approach. As our phased-in start to the school year approaches, I’d like to share with you some key dates:

September 2, 3, 8 and 9 will be Superintendent Conference Days.

September 10 - 18 will be 100% remote for all students, and all of these days will be half days.

September 21 - 25 will be 100% remote for all students, and all of these days will be full days.

Starting September 29 we will begin our in-person classes for Kindergarten through 5th grade and the Hybrid learning plan for 6th through 12th grade. Those families that have opted for the Remote plan through January will continue with remote learning. https://www.henhudschools.org/site/default.aspx?PageType=3&DomainID=8&ModuleInstanceID=10192&ViewID=6446EE88-D30C-497E-9316-3F8874B3E108&RenderLoc=0&FlexDataID=38219&PageID=9

In an email sent to members of the Class of 2020 this week, Principal James Mackin announced that the “Big Reveal” drive-in event, scheduled for July 19 at the Cortlandt train station, has been postponed indefinitely.

“Our hope was to have this event as a way for the senior class to come together one last time to celebrate,” said Mackin. “However, given the recent news regarding graduation events in Westchester and Rockland Counties, Metro-North has made the decision to not allow use of its parking facility for our event.”

The event will be postponed indefinitely, based on the Metro-North decision and district concerns regarding public health, safety, insurance and liability.

A video tribute to the Class of 2020 is still being produced, and it will be shared with all of the graduates and their families once it is complete.

The Hendrick Hudson School District will be closed on Monday, May 25, 2020, in observance of Memorial Day. No online instruction will take place that day.

In previous years, the district has added the Friday before Memorial Day to the holiday weekend, as a “give back” when there are unused snow days. However, this year, the governor’s Executive Order states that school districts may not use emergency days for this purpose.

The district is still awaiting guidance regarding when the last day of school will be, in light of the fact that Spring Break was cancelled this year. As soon as a decision is made, it will be announced via email and on the district website and social media platforms.

Dear Hendrick Hudson Families,

The New York State Assembly and Senate have introduced legislation designed to increase revenue to the Hendrick Hudson School District, specifically aimed at replacing tax revenue loss as Indian Point closes.

We are asking residents and staff to sign a digital petition as a signal of support and to urge lawmakers to approve this vitally important legislation for our school community.

Information on the legislation, and the petition, can be found here: http://chng.it/YDDWWWJJNs

This is a valuable opportunity for members of the Hendrick Hudson school community to weigh in on important policy shaping the financial future of our region.

Our community, the local taxpayers, need assurances that they will not be taxed out of their homes and that this legislation will create a guaranteed and reliable revenue stream to assist in the long-term financial planning of our school district and our local residents.

We wholeheartedly support this legislation.

Regards,
Joseph Hochreiter, Superintendent

The sun was shining brightly yesterday, but the smiles may have been even brighter, as FGL staff put on a drive-through parade for their students and families, right in front of the school! Staff stayed by their parked cars, which were decorated with colorful heartfelt signs and balloons, and families were able to drive through the parking lot, keeping everybody safe inside their cars, while also being able to smile, wave and honk their appreciation.

“We needed this, and we saw that the children and their parents needed it, too,” said Principal Donna Torrisi. “It was the most wonderful feeling of unity that I have experienced in 34 years as an educator.”

Many thanks to John Anderson and his staff for keeping things orderly and safe, and the PTA for cookies and flowers for the teachers.

Six BMMS choral students were scheduled to perform at SUNY Purchase last month as part of the All-County Chorus Festival. Although the in-person performance was cancelled, the students, accompanied by choral teacher Kimberly Dunkin on piano, have created a virtual performance of one of the songs they had planned to sing at the festival: “Song for Peace,” by Allister MacGillivray.

“This song is so appropriate for us at Hen Hud, in light of the current global situation, because it is about sailing together and braving even the toughest of storms,” said Dunkin.

The featured students are: Daphne Evans & Paulina Lastras-Castrejon, sopranos;
Mia O'Malley and Benjamin Ramirez, altos; Alec Elkin & Max Lipton, baritones; and soloists Max Lipton and Paulina Lastras-Castrejon.

We appreciate the community’s patience as we ready this wonderful asset for public use. The district is taking great care to ensure that security measures are in place in order to protect this very significant capital investment.

post_text: For the past five years, the Montrose Business Association has honored a local veteran. This year, the group is honoring the memory of a Hen Hud alumnus (class of 1966), Charles "Chuck" Wolfe. Wolfe served two tours in Vietnam. He earned a Silver Star and returned as a Sergeant on the first tour. On the second tour, he saved many lives and was wounded in the process; for this he received the Purple Heart, another Silver Star, and a recommendation for the Congressional Medal of Honor. The association will hold a ceremony this Saturday, November 23, at 1:00 pm at the gazebo in Veterans Park, adjacent to the Cortlandt Community Volunteer Ambulance Corps. Some of the high school’s Treblemakers will sing at the ceremony.

post_text: First grade students in Janet Ho's class at Furnace Woods got some help from Superintendent Hochreiter and Principal Kramer as they created papier-mache dragons to celebrate the trilogy they'd recently read: My Father's Dragon, Elmer and the Dragon, and The Dragons of Blueland, all by Ruth Stiles Gannett. The project is a beloved tradition in the class, one that former students continue to talk about and remember fondly!

post_text: November 11 is Veterans Day, and for the second year in a row, the BMMS Student Government created a Hallway of Heroes in the school lobby, as part of its "Salute to our Veterans." SG committee members collected photos of family members who have served in the military from BMMS students and staff, and hung them all around the school's entry, along with flags and signage. #InspireExploreDiscover.
